comment.author: 18753752@N00
comment._content: But, as we all know, that isn't Frances Noyes.

comment.author: 30085166@N00
comment._content: And we know that Hedwig isn't dressed as Liberty, but as Columbia. Poor Hedwig Reicher, to lose her identity on the Internets! And she got such a splendid writeup in the New York Times in 1909! And on top of that she remains in the shadow her brother, Frank Reicher, whose IMDb page is so much longer than hers.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content:
NYT article on February 7, 1913  [http://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9907EED81E3AE633A25754C0A9649C946296D6CF ] says that Florence Fleming Noyes will wear sandals as Liberty -- however cold the weather.  The article reassures the public that most will wear wool and therefore not be cold!  Perhaps Florence Noyes is behind and to left of Hedwig Reicher.

The article also suggests that the building is the U.S. Treasury.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: LOC's history of the Woman Suffrage Procession (and Pageant) confirms that that is the Treasury building: www.loc.gov/loc/lcib/9803/suffrage.html
